Hi there! does anyone know if there’s a way to listen to deep link intent filters only when the app is in a certain activity?

What I currently got is a deep link working using my custom scheme who redirects the app to activity B. When the app is in the activity C and receives that Intent, the activity B is triggered again. Is there any way to avoid it? I’m thinking about disabling the Activity using PackageManager but it seems quite overkilling…am I missing anything?

hey guys, I have a basic ripple on my grid item and it contains an image that is used for a transition onClick. is there any way for the ripple to actually be shown on click except by delaying the transition for like 100ms?
<@U0548MM6B>: how do you mean?
you want the ripple effect to finish before starting the transition?
the transition starts on a down so you miss the ripple ??
you could post the event to a handler with a delay
just be careful not to let them stack
I want ripple to even show before the activity transition starts, currently posting a weakref handler, but wondering if there is a better way.
I still don’t really follow <@U0548MM6B> :smile:
It sounds like you want to start the transition on a up event
:point_down: start ripple … :point_up_2: start transition ?
and it does start, but if the press isn’t long enough or if it’s just a tap, the ripple doesnt even show - unless I use a delay
Oh y
that’s a side effect. I’ve seen that before
using handlers seems like an ugly hack ughhh :disappointed:
y it does :smile:
I remember coming across something like that before but I can’t remember where
my phone is stuffed with example / test apps and I can’t find it on here
:joy:
you’re complaining because your app is fast? :smile:
so it’s probably somewhere lost in the gazillion test projects I have on my server

Hey all, need to pass a callback to a fragment for its nested fragment to use, but passing it in the constructor makes lint tell me I should be ashamed of myself, are there a recommended way of doing it? can I pass callbacks to a bundle?
oh man asking this question is like bringing obama to north korean border
usually fragments are passed a bundle through a newInstance method
or you can use a setCallback(Callback callbackToBePassed) method exposed on the fragment
fragments need an empty constructor as they can be destroyed and rebuilt by the framework several times
Yeah, I’ve heard that newInstance does not play well with non-empty constructors sometimes, will try exposing a method and see where it leads me, thanks <@U08N9CH9V>
the _usual_ option is to implement an interface on the activity and cast it in the onAttach method
setting it to null in dettach
hi btw
Had some trouble with that with nested fragments, but I could look harder for a way to make it work. :simple_smile:
are you usign a viewpager? if not avoid nested fragments
Well both solutions work fine.. It just doesnt look pretty :wink:
I am using a viewpager
yeah, it doesn’t look pretty in any way, especially because fragments are ugly
No way around atleast some spaghetti :stuck_out_tongue:
so you can use a setCallback, you can pass it via bundle, you can using events instead of callback, or maybe subscribing them to a bus…so many choices
viewPagers are different, you always control how the fragments are built as opposed to a fragment inside an activity
you can just have a setCallback() method and directly set it in the fragment instance
I can’t wait to go back and rewrite fragments into custom views
just take into consideration that you will be setting it before any lifecycle method is called
also to avoid spaghetti do `activity <-> parent frag <-> pager adapter <-> child frags`
If I wanted to avoid spaghetti I would go for an event bus.
as long as you dont have 10000 different events to maintain and keep track off
I dont really like events in view related stuff tbh, I really dont think it avoids spaghetti
you will end up with 10000 events and you know it :stuck_out_tongue:
I know :blush:
“I wonder where this event comes from"
ahah yea, or where the one that is triggered in this goes to

Hi, someone can explain me the difference between `switchMap` and `flatMap` talking about RX ?
`flatMap` executes mapped observables simultaneously while `switchMap` unsubscribes from the current observable when it receives a new one.
<@U0MJLRK96>: TL;TR: `switchMap` is useful when you need to switch to another `Observable` and stop receiving emission from previos

text: If it saves time use a relative
be pragmatic and don’t pre optimize until it is measured to be an issue
plus this is a really shallow heirarchy so it won’t be a big deal
“RelativeLayout will always do two measure passes"
sure
i guess there is a time and a place to optimize
and i probably dont have to worry about this in my case
in any case
i tried going with a RelativeLayout
and still have the issue i mentioned above
so from the original snippet. I see the scrollview overlapping the footer bar and you are correcting with padding. that seems bad to me
the next is the frame layout wrapping the two items inside of the scrollview provides no protection for the over lap
I’m not familiar with the coordinator layout but I imagine the correct path of action is to add behaviour to keep the scroll view above the footer?

I do most of my complex layouts with a relative layout because it lends for a MUCH better mental model of behavior. In fact the new percent relative layout I was able to use to replace a giant mess of weighted linears in a graphic intro tour.

this is my current layout
<https://gist.github.com/lawloretienne/1c840ffc2724f2ea3e488ff323228d43>
start with getting rid of all the linear layouts inside of that relative
why the nested scroll view
i just was testing it out
no particular reason
i tried with a scrollview and that had an issue as well
Im playing with it right now.
thanks for looking into this
ive been struggling with this for awhile
i might have to simplify the layout if i cant get the behavior i want
but im trying to avoid that

<@U0QPPQ8GG|trevjonez> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/trevjonez/F0YA5RRQX/-.xml|Untitled> and commented: Still some linear inside the relative to make the side by side and centering simple.(something weird with relatives and gravity) Things to note is the outer relative keeps the scroll view above the footer thus removing the padding.

file.name: -.xml
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<RelativeLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
    android:id="@+id/main_content"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"

initial_comment.comment: Still some linear inside the relative to make the side by side and centering simple.(something weird with relatives and gravity) Things to note is the outer relative keeps the scroll view above the footer thus removing the padding.

attachments.text: Spinrilla, the 800-lb gorilla of free hip-hop mixtapes. Access thousands of hip-hop mixtapes in your pocket. Use the Spinrilla app to listen to the newest hip-hop mixtapes released for free from your favorite artists and DJs. Offline mode allows listening to mixtapes when an internet connection isn't present. Please note: If songs are stopping repeatedly please download the song to play it from your device. Some connections will not be able to stream songs due to slowness. Spinrilla is in no way affiliated with DatPiff, LiveMixtapes, or MyMixtapez. Follow @Spinrilla on Twitter for more updates.
